head.title: Rankings May Change Focus at Law Schools

hedline.hl1: Rankings May Change Focus at Law Schools

abstract.p: David A Hollander letter comments on Feb 19 article on mail campaign by law school deans against US News and World Report's law-school rankings

block.p: In your Feb. 19 front-page article on a mail campaign by law school deans against U.S. News and World Report's law-school rankings, we learn the following:
In your Feb. 19 front-page article on a mail campaign by law school deans against U.S. News and World Report's law-school rankings, we learn the following:

The Law School Admission Council (the people who write and administer the Law School Admission Test) financed the $50,000 mailing; the deans claim that the rankings place too much weight on the admission test, causing a ''pernicious effect'' that causes the law schools to be ''more inclined to look at a candidate's test score and play down other factors'' in admissions.

So have these law school deans been compromising their admissions processes emphasizing higher test scores because they were more worried about a popularity contest than the fairest evaluation of candidates? Does anyone believe these deans?
Law schools have been overemphasizing the Law School Admission Test in the admission process since long before U.S. News began its ranking.
DAVID A. HOLLANDER New York, Feb. 19, 1998
The writer is co-author of The Princeton Review's Best Law Schools (1998).
